req.def: The code shall be maintainable and simple to read.

refs.ref: Above all, this is the primary goal for any openly developed project as without the ability to read the code, it's impossible for people to contribute and get involved.
[current code too complex, scares off users]
I don't think I am [willing to trade off some performance for clearly written code]. Performance is too damned important in the XML world
You're not going to get a diverse developer community built around code that is too damned hard to read...

req.def: The parser should have the smallest possible memory footprint.
req.edReqNote: This needs refinement of target applications, quantification of sizes.

refs.ref: This means small distribution size (JAR file) and small memory footprint.

req.def: The parser shall be designed so as to allow deployment of minimal subsets suitable for low-end, memory-constrained applications

refs.ref: It should be possible to build a parser as a set of Jar files so that a smaller parser can be assembled which fits the need of a particular implementation. For example, in TV sets do you really need validation?

Where I am now we use XML as a wire format, so the data volume is small, and parsing takes place on the client (the customer's e-commerce environment) and on the server. Small footprint (memory *and* disk) are much more important in this context than speed or even validation.
... many applications could benefit ...

req.def: The parser shall be optimized in a way that is compatible with modern virtual machines such as HotSpot.
Optimizations that interfere with readability, modularity, or size should be shunned.
The parser should have the smallest possible distribution (JAR) size.
req.edReqNote: This needs refinement of target applications, quantification of sizes.

refs.ref: This means small distribution size (JAR file) and small memory footprint.
These two requirements [small memory footprint, small jar size -ed] are in direct conflict.

req.def: The design of the parser should be documented, with diagrams where they are more expressive than text.

refs.ref: ... would benefit greatly from requirements and design documentation; most especially some diagrams. I find that a dozen or so good diagrams often do a better job of conveying the design and, perhaps more importantly, the design approach or philosophy, than written documents.

req.def: The parser should have the characteristics needed for it to be included in the JDK.
The parser should be upwardly compatible with Xerces.

refs.ref: Whatever happened to making things upgrade compatiable.

req.def: The parser must be cleanly modular.

refs.ref: [star vs. pipeline]

req.def: Development should be coordinated with xerces-c.

refs.ref: I'd also like to see this be coordinated with the xerces-c developers ... it would be nice to keep the two parsers in sync so that changes to one parser and relatively easy to implement in the other.
I disagree...
Java is a very different language from C++, and you need different strategies.
...there's much to be gained by keeping the overall architecture and design the same between the two versions.
[forcing deep similarity is bad]
...trying to find one design that fits both languages well will produce one design that doesn't quite fit either language.
Let's push for high-level designs that can accommodate any OO language...

req.def: The parser shall support SAX2.

The parser should be suitable for implementation of XSLT (especially Xalan2. Subrequirements:
1) SAX2, of course.
2) Read-only, memory conservative, high performance DOM subset. In some ways, this is optional, since the alternative is that the XSLT processor implement it's own DOM, as it does today. But it would be neat and simpler if only one DOM implementation needed to exist.
2a) Document-order indexes or API as a DOM extension. I know of few or no conformant XSLT processors that can do without this.
2b) [optional] isWhite() method as a DOM extensions (pure telling of whether or not the text contains non-whitespace), for performance reasons.
2c) Some sort of weak reference, where nodes could be released if not referenced, and then rebuilt if requested. For performance and memory footprint.
3) parse-next function, with added control over buffer size.
4) Some sort of way to tell if a SAX char buffer is going to be overwritten, so data doesn't have to be copied until this occurs.
5) Serialization support, as is currently in Assaf's classes.
6) Schema data-type support, which will be needed for XSLT2, and Xalan 2.0 extensions.
8) Small core footprint for standalone, compiled stylesheet capability, for use on small devices. This would need to include the Serializer. I'm not sure if this should really be a separate micro-parser?
The parser shall validate XML 1.0.
The parser shall support namespaces.
The parser shall support DOM Level 2.
The parser shall support XML Schema.
The parser shall support XPath.
The parser should support XInclude.
The parser should support write validation of a DOM tree or revalidation.
The parser should support grammar access for both DTD and Schema.
No significant speed penalty should be invoked for unused features, notably validation. When not validating, the parser should run almost as fast as a non-validating parser.
The parser should provide best-of-breed performance across all JIT's (not just Hotspot).

refs.ref: -1 (on JDK 1.1)

req.def: The parser should support grammar caching and precompilation.
The parser should provide mid to upper range validation performance across all JVMs.
The parser should provide a reasonable core (fast!) upon which to layer JDOM

refs.ref: JDOM is an important up and coming API that already has established a large and rapidly growing groundswell of support and in the developer community.

req.def: The project should produce testcases for both conformance and benchmarking.
The parse shall support SAX 1
The core parser should not directly support any tree model.

refs.ref:
My understanding of the design, which I think is good, is that the "core" actually doesn't directly support any tree model.
API Layer JDOM DOM SAX2
Core Layer Java parser code

req.def: The parser shall support Java 1.1
The parser should support loading and validating only certainrequested portions of a document -- a useful feature when dealing with large xml databases, for example.
The parser shall support the XML Information Set.
The parser should support pull model parsing.
The parser should support compilation of a high-speed customized parser based on a W3C schema.
The DOM should emit events to interested listeners when changes are made to the DOM
